claim.text: LLMs impersonating children of different ages can recover human-like developmental stages of exploration strategies
claim.exact_quote: In a multi-armed bandit task, we find that LLMs pretending to be children of different ages recover human-like developmental stages of exploration.

evidence.evidence_text: LLMs impersonating children showed higher levels of directed exploration compared to adults, matching psychological literature
evidence.limitations: Limited to one type of task (two-armed bandit)
evidence.exact_quote: LLMs pretending to be older explored their environment less (β = -0.03, p < .001) and exploited more (β = 0.04, p < .001) in the ages between 2–20. This pattern is in line with several results from the psychological literature which also found that children show higher levels of directed exploration than adults

conclusion.limitations: Limited to two-armed bandit task only; may not generalize to other exploration tasks

claim.text: LLMs impersonating domain experts perform better than non-domain experts in language-based reasoning tasks
claim.exact_quote: In a language-based reasoning task, we find that LLMs impersonating domain experts perform better than LLMs impersonating non-domain experts.

evidence.evidence_text: Task experts outperformed domain experts who outperformed non-domain experts across MMLU domains
evidence.exact_quote: when the LLM is asked to impersonate the task expert, the performance is the highest. Similarly, the domain expert personas perform better than the non-domain expert personas. This trend holds for all four MMLU domains

conclusion.limitations: Limited to MMLU dataset; tested on only two LLMs

claim.text: LLMs impersonating experts perform better at describing objects in their domain of expertise
claim.exact_quote: We find that impersonation can improve performance: an LLM prompted to be a bird expert describes birds better than one prompted to be a car expert.

evidence.evidence_text: Bird expert better described birds while car expert better described cars
evidence.exact_quote: car mechanic persona's descriptions performs better than ornithologist's when recognizing cars

conclusion.limitations: Only tested on birds and cars; may not generalize to other domains

claim.text: LLMs show gender and racial biases in their impersonated descriptions
claim.exact_quote: However, impersonation can also uncover LLMs' biases: an LLM prompted to be a man describes cars better than one prompted to be a woman.

evidence.evidence_text: Racial and gender biases found in description performance
evidence.exact_quote: While the black performs better in car classification, the white performs better in bird classification... while the woman performs clearly better than man for bird classification, the trend is not as strong for car classification although man performs slightly better than woman

conclusion.limitations: Limited to binary gender/race categories; may reflect training data biases rather than real-world biases

claim.text: LLMs impersonating older personas obtain higher rewards in bandit tasks than younger personas
claim.exact_quote: Younger personas, i.e., 2- and 4-year-old personas, obtain a smaller reward than older ones, i.e., 13- and 20-year-old personas.

evidence.evidence_text: Older personas obtained higher rewards in bandit task
evidence.exact_quote: LLMs impersonating older participants generate higher average rewards until age 20 (β = 0.17, p < .001)

conclusion.limitations: Effect plateaus after age 20; tested only up to age 60

claim.text: LLMs impersonating older personas explore less and exploit more in bandit tasks
claim.exact_quote: LLMs pretending to be older explored their environment less (β = −0.03, p < .001) and exploited more (β = 0.04, p < .001) in the ages between 2–20.

evidence.evidence_text: Older personas showed less exploration and more exploitation
evidence.exact_quote: LLMs pretending to be older explored their environment less (β = -0.03, p < .001) and exploited more (β = 0.04, p < .001) in the ages between 2–20

conclusion.limitations: Statistical significance only shown for ages 2-20, not 20-60

claim.text: Task expert personas perform better than domain expert personas in MMLU tasks
claim.exact_quote: When the LLM is asked to impersonate the task expert, the performance is the highest... the domain expert personas perform better than the non-domain expert personas.

evidence.evidence_text: Task experts outperformed domain experts on MMLU tasks
evidence.exact_quote: for World Religions and Human Aging, we observe that the task expert performs much better than the corresponding domain expert personas

conclusion.limitations: Performance varies by subject area; some tasks show weaker expert advantage

claim.text: ChatGPT shows larger effects of impersonation compared to Vicuna-13B
claim.location: Results - Vision and Language Task Design section
claim.exact_quote: Overall, we find that ChatGPT shows larger effects, probably due to its access to more diverse (fine-tuning) data.

evidence.evidence_text: ChatGPT showed more pronounced effects of impersonation
evidence.exact_quote: The progression is particularly pronounced for ChatGPT... Overall, we find that ChatGPT shows larger effects, probably due to its access to more diverse (fine-tuning) data

conclusion.limitations: Limited quantitative comparison between models; insufficient statistical evidence presented
